Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if, in view of the violent assaults on gardaí on Border duty recently and the danger of a recurrence of such incidents, he will state the action, if any, he intends to take to protect gardaí on such duty against such violence.

I assume that the question refers to three incidents that have occurred within the past ten days near the Border when members of the Garda Síochána were confronted and assaulted by armed men. These are very serious incidents—especially, needless to say, the firing of shots—but the question of action to protect the gardaí in such circumstances raises important issues of a fundamental nature.

MainHeading.P: The situation that has now arisen is not a new one. Since the foundation of the State the Garda Síochána have been an unarmed force and on a great many occasions down the years they have had to face armed men in the discharge of their duties. They have courageously and successfully faced such challenges in the past and they are doing so again to-day. I am sure that I am expressing the wish of the entire House when I take this opportunity to pay them that deserved tribute. It is the policy of the Government that the Garda Síochána should continue to be an unarmed police force and my information is that policy has consistently been and still is strongly supported at all levels within the Garda Síochána. I must emphasise that there is continuous and very close co-operation between the Garda and the Army both at operational and planning levels. The extent of the assistance that is appropriate or best in any particular situation is a matter for professional assessment by the Garda in consultation where necessary with the Army.

For obvious reasons I could not agree to reveal full details about the nature and extent of the assistance that the Army are providing for the Garda or to give information regarding the circumstances in which the Garda would seek such assistance, or as to changes that may be made from time to time in regard to the arrangements that exist, as such information would be liable to be of substantial benefit to illegal groups. I can, however, give the House my unqualified assurance that co-operation between the two Forces—the Garda and the Army—is excellent.

Speaker.P: We on this side of the House, deplore these attacks on gardaí, from whatever source, and we should like to be associated with the remarks of the Minister in his tribute to the bravery of the gardaí in their service to the State over the years. The Minister does mention the matter of the Army in the context of his reply. Could he say what is the procedure for calling the Army to the assistance of the Garda? Could he give us some indication in this matter? I appreciate the delicacy of my question but there appears to be some concern about the elaborateness or otherwise of the procedure of the Garda calling the Army to their assistance. Is there any difficulty there?

I am not aware of any concern and I am certainly not aware of any difficulty in this regard. As I have said in my reply there is continuous and very close co-operation between the Garda and Army both at operational and planning levels. My advice is that this co-operation works in practice extremely well and to the satisfaction of both forces.
For instance, at checkpoints along the Border, at night time particularly, are Army personnel present with Garda personnel at each checkpoint?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: That seems to be a separate question.
I am just trying to be helpful in this matter.

Quite clearly, I am unable to say how any particular checkpoint is manned at any particular time. But the point I should make and which possibly the Deputy is seeking to elicit from me is that if the Garda want Army presence at any time it is readily and speedily available.

Could I ask the Minister if his attention has been drawn to an incident along the Border where an unarmed detective-sergeant disarmed an armed man and if the Minister would care to make any comment on it?

I am aware of the incident. It confirms what I have said of the courageous way in which the Garda face such challenges today as they have done in the past. I should like to take this opportunity of congratulating the officer in question for his personal bravery. Indeed, I think it would be no harm if I were to mention at this stage a news item that appeared in today's papers. This item, which seemed to me to receive an inordinately small amount of attention from the media, dealt with the seizure by the guards yesterday of the largest amount of ammunition they have yet seized, together with a very large amount of explosive material. This practical example of police efficiency received little attention in comparison with other incidents where gardaí are attacked or embarrassed.
Is the Minister satisfied with Garda living and office accommodation generally around the Border area, having regard to the large increase in the number on duty in those areas?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

The Deputy will have heard me, in my Estimate speech, indicate my dissatisfaction with Garda accommodation generally and, in the course of which, I indicated the steps that had been taken to improve this. Extra demands are being made on Garda stations and Garda space, particularly in the Border areas. I have expressed my concern that as much as possible be done to alleviate any hardship that might result to the Garda.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Intervention Beef.

Speaker.P: I must first thank the Chair for allowing me raise this matter on the Adjournment because it has very serious implications for the cattle trade and, as stated in The Irish Independent of last Saturday, has led to a crisis in our meat trade. I think that very fittingly sums up the whole situation.

As I mentioned today, this morning I was at one of our biggest cold stores in the country. To my surprise I found that cattle taken into intervention on Tuesday, 23rd April, were being put into containers to be shipped off this morning, just sufficient time after they had been frozen.

MainHeading.P: Looking around, I am surprised to find cattle taken into intervention on Tuesday 23rd, put into containers, and shipped off this morning, the 25th, just sufficient time for them to be frozen down. There was no storage accommodation available. That has applied for quite some time. All our stores are full and we have to get beasts across to some other cold store in Europe or elsewhere. Now, normally prices are highest towards the end of April and into the second week of May, when they hit a peak, because this is the period of lowest production and highest prices. But, even at that, there are 1,000 tons going into intervention at the moment. Now the Minister was warned about this situation as far back as February of this year by way of Parliamentary question on 13th February last. He was warned about the importation of beef from a third country and he was asked what effect that would have on us. He said, at column 594 of volume 270 of the Official Report:
Special arrangements for imports of beef into the Community from Argentina and Uruguay are contained in trade agreements which the Community has concluded with these countries.

The main provision of these agreements in regard to beef is an undertaking by the Community to endeavour, in the application of the common market organisation, to suspend or reduce levies on imports of certain categories of frozen beef, including frozen beef for processing. If such action were to disturb or risk disturbing the Community beef market, the Community may invoke a safeguard clause until the market situation has settled itself.
In reply to a supplementary question as to the effect of these agreements, the Minister said:
Practically no effect on our beef exports because they apply only to calves or very young cattle and it is mainly a traditional trade to Italy for feed lot production of beef.

The Minister misled the House in that reply because last year 900,000 tons of beef were imported into the Community. Even if there is a slight reduction in this year from 900,000 tons to 600,000 tons, the fact is that the Minister, as a member of the Council of Ministers, allowed this agreement to go through and countries like Yugoslavia, Poland, Hungry, Rumania, the Argentine, Brazil, Uruguay and Australia are all exporting beef into the European Community, more than what we ourselves are doing and we are members of the Community. The Minister agreed to these imports again this year. These imports will have a very detrimental effect on our cattle exports and prices. They will have a very detrimental effect on our farmers' incomes.

Traditionally, the cattle trade and the beef industry is the biggest industry we have. It is our biggest exporter and it brings in revenue which offsets our balance of payments. But our Minister has seen fit to allow this beef to be imported into the Community to the detriment of our exporters and farmers. All the relevant information can be found in a tabular statement, behind which the Minister sheltered, on Wednesday, 13th February, at column 592 of volume 270 of the Official Report.

In today's papers we find that Britain is getting away with her cheap food policy. This is a policy which has been detrimental to our farmers for generations and we believed that, once we got into Europe, we would be able to shake off the shackles of British policy. Today's Irish Press carries the banner line “The last straw to Irish exporters”. Five years ago Britain imposed a ban on Uruguayan beef. At the time she was importing 3,200 tons a month from Uruguay. She is now going to import frozen hind quarters from Uruguay, from West Germany and from Denmark and some of this meat will sell as low as 5p per pound on the British market. I wonder why Britain is allowed to do this at such short notice. I wonder whether she got sanction from the EEC to do this. Is this something designed purely and simply to depress the price of beef for the benefit of her own people with, possibly, an election in view later on this year?

When Mr. Callaghan went over recently to Brussels to re-negotiate Britain's terms of entry into the EEC it was rather surprising to find the sympathetic treatment he received from the EEC. He talked tough about what Britain wanted. It is time our Minister and our Government adopted a similar line and took really firm action with the Commission in Brussels for the purposes of safeguarding our industry. We get the impression that the EEC is being controlled by civil servants in Brussels who do not appear to be competent to deal with problems in a satisfactory manner. We must bring real pressure to bear on these people and on their political masters, the Council of Ministers, in order to safeguard our own future and our cattle industry. This comes at a time of the year when our production of beef is at its lowest and they were talking of a mountain of beef of 60,000 tons. What will this figure be in September, October or November when this country could produce 60,000 tons in any one month? What are we doing to safeguard our industry?

The Agricultural Commissioner stated yesterday that there was not storage capacity in the Community to take the amount of beef likely to be eligible for intervention. He said the system was never devised for that purpose. The Commissioner admitted that the whole situation was very tricky but he could offer no short-term solution to the problem of imbalance between supply, price and demand in the beef sector. That Commissioner had the audacity to say that the 60,000 tons was only 1 per cent of the Community's consumption. He said it would have very little impact and at that time he was comparing it with the butter mountain last year which was 5 per cent.

What is our Minister, and our Government, doing to safeguard this industry? If there is no storage for our beef in the latter end of this year what are we going to do with it? Grass will be running out at that stage and the farmers will have made commitments as to the number of cattle they will be keeping in the winter period. There will be 138,000 extra cattle to feed at that time even taking account of the normal amount of exports and killings.
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has told us that he cannot get nitrogen which is vitally needed to provide winter fodder.

Speaker.P: That is hardly relevant to this matter.

I accept the ruling of the Chair. At present the Germans and the Danes are supplying beef which is heavily subsidised to go into Britain. In Britain it is undercutting our beef by as much as 10p per lb., using our EEC funds to ruin our oldest and best market. In trying to relieve the situation by exporting some of our beef to countries outside the EEC, such as America, we have to pay a big levy, up to £65 to £75 per ton. One would imagine that the Community would be paying us this money to save them the embarrassment of having to put it into intervention. The Minister did a song and dance about getting it reduced by about £15 or £20 per ton five or six months ago but we still have this heavy tax on beef exported from this country to countries outside the EEC.

Our exporters have been endeavouring to secure fresh markets for our beef. For example, we had been sending 250 cattle a week to Switzerland, but the most recent changes in the MCA have made it impossible to continue this trade. Therefore, this market of 250 cattle per week has been lost to the Irish farmer. We are also sending cattle to Portugal but they are also carrying a very heavy penalty. It is hard to say how long this can last.

What is our Minister doing to ensure that these markets are kept going and to ensure that we are not being overruled completely by the civil servants in Brussels who appear to have no regard for the Irish farmer, the Irish Government or our Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries? In this regard I must compliment our former Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries, Deputy J. Gibbons, who heckled the Agricultural Commissioner at a session of the European Parliament in Brussels yesterday. I wish our own Minister was doing something like that and was fighting his corner like Mr. Callaghan, the British Foreign Secretary, did for Britain.

The British Minister for Agriculture when he was interviewed on television on his return from discussions in Brussels, discussions which were attended by our Minister, was a happy man and he did not try to hide his satisfaction with the situation. He knew what he had sold and I am sure he also knew that the poor Irish farmer was going to pay the piper for some of the concessions that our Minister had agreed to let him away with.

MainHeading.P: The export of forward stores and live beef cattle to England has drastically fallen off this year and those in the trade are aware that very few English buyers are attending our marts at present. I hope that even at this late hour, after a newspaper has succeeded in making everybody aware of the crisis in our meat trade, our Minister will act firmly when he goes to negotiate next week.

When this fact was highlighted by Members on this side of the House last February the Minister had the audacity to mislead the House by saying that it would have no effect whatever on our beef exports. The Agricultural Commissioner has admitted that the EEC have not the storage facilties to take our beef at the end of this year when production will be at its peak.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton) Mark A. Clinton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton)
Speaker.P: We have certainly gone a long way from the question and the answer. I will remind the House of the question and the reply which I think was more than adequate. The question was to ask the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries whether all beef offered in the next few weeks for sale to intervention can be accepted. I could have simply said: “Yes” and sat down, but I did not. I said that I am advised that the intervention storage facilities will be adequate during the next few weeks for all beef offered for which freezing down facilities are available either at the meat factories themselves or at the public cold stores.

That was a complete and absolute answer to the question asked. Now the Deputy has rambled around the whole countryside. It was very good of the Ceann Comhairle to let him do that, because it is good to allow people to let off steam from time to time. I do not know whether to put down the Deputy's lack of knowledge to innocence or ignorance, or to a deliberate attempt to mislead the country on this matter. He said he put me on warning on 13th February last through a Parliamentary Question that there would be trouble because of imports of third country beef. Who does he think he is fooling?

MainHeading.P: I was responsible with the French Minister, and with the backing of the Italian Minister, for having a special meeting called on 19th December last. He tells me he warned me in February that there would be trouble about this. Did anybody ever hear such nonsense? What was the outcome? We drew attention in no uncertain terms to the situation which was arising because of over-supply of meat on the European market. We sought the only course open to us at the time. We used the machinery which was there to be used, that is, the safeguard clause, to have a complete embargo on beef from third countries into the EEC.

The case was very strongly made by the French Minister and myself and supported by the Italian Minister. We gave all the facts and figures and all the difficulties arising from the depressed state of the market, and the future prospects. This was put to a vote. Four countries voted in favour of introducing an embargo and five voted against. What would Deputy Crinion have done? Is he as foolish as the various other people around the country who say: “Why did not Clinton use the veto?” The EEC would be very glad to get rid of the problem of Ireland tomorrow if that is what we want, but I do not think it is what we want.

There are people who try to give the impression that we got no benefits from membership of the EEC. Last year in subsidies for agriculture alone we got £40 million and our contribution to the EEC was £4½ million. This year on our estimate of the new prices we will get £60 million in subsidies. People ought to waken up to the position. The more Deputy Crinions we have in this country crying and howling about the dangers of intervention and the difficulties of intervention, the more the price will become depressed. He is doing himself as a producer an immense amount of harm when he supports the propaganda in the paper about all these difficulties.

Speaker.P: Is the Minister attacking the IFA?

I am giving the facts. We now have 12,000 tons of beef in intervention and that is the total amount of beef offered to the Irish Government for intervention. We never failed to take that frozen beef when it was offered within the prescribed period of six days. This has been a wonderful performance. Civil servants have been accused of doing all sorts of terrible things but I think the civil servants in this case have done a miraculous job in finding space for this amount of beef. This was a whole new business. You do not create storage facilities and freezing facilities for these quantities of beef overnight. To decry the efforts of the Department in this case is deplorable. I do not agree with anybody who tells me that £19.25 per cwt. is a deplorable price and neither does Deputy Crinion agree, but he comes into this House deliberately, and for no other reason, to criticise me as Minister and ask what did I do. I have told him some of the things I have done. I pressed continuously for effective controls on imports from third countries long before I got any warning from Deputy Crinion.
The Minister failed.

He then complains about the effects of monetary compensatory amounts and transitional compensatory amounts. What he is saying, in fact, is that my predecessor, and the Minister who mainly negotiated the terms of our accession, did a bad job. He is asking me to re-negotiate this in a more favourable way. This has been thrown in my face on several occasions. I said in this House at the time that I did not consider that a bad job was done. I said that at a time when I was sitting where Deputy Crinion is sitting now. I said we had nothing to bargain with and that we got into the EEC because we had friends in the EEC, and that I considered in those circumstances that quite a reasonably good job was done. Again, a lot of credit goes to the civil servants involved and to the Minister concerned.
The English Minister got away with murder.

He did nothing of the sort. Anything the English Minister got at the recent negotiations was within the terms of accession, nothing more, nothing less. He got permission to pay subsidies from the British Exchequer. I got these subsidies from FEOGA for the Irish producers, at FEOGA's expense, not at the expense of the Irish Exchequer. I would have thought that Deputy Crinion would be generous enough at least to acknowledge this.
Very few are being paid.

I will tell Deputy Crinion what is being paid. Practically all claims for beef purchased for intervention which were received prior to 31st March will have been paid by to-day. They amount to £5.4 million. This excepts claims for £121,000 which are under query because of incomplete documentation or absence of documentation. A further £1 million will be paid by the end of this week. This will practically clear all claims received up to 24th April. Could a better job be done? What is Deputy Crinion talking about? He is simply talking through his hat.
The Minister should tell the Irish farmers.

It was an enormous job to set up the machinery to deal with a completely new business. In the recent arrangements we had to man the border and take over that difficult job in relation to pigs and beef. We had to intervene not only for beef but for cattle as well. In the case of cattle the payments are just as satisfactory. I would be the first to admit that we had initial difficulty. This is a very big and complicated organisation. We had difficulties in getting the necessary staff together, in getting the staff experienced, and in educating people in the use of the documentation which we are required to have for the EEC. For Deputy Crinion to come in here and try to misrepresent the position is to do an immense amount of harm to the producer. He is supporting this scare business in the papers. Being a farmer himself and a well-known beef producer, he should be the last man to come in here and misrepresent the position and worsen the position of the producer by so doing.
What will the Minister do next week?

It suits the people in the trade. The lower the price of cattle goes the better they like it. If that is what Deputy Crinion is aiming at, that is what he is achieving. If that is his interest, simply and solely for party political reasons, he is doing an immense amount of harm to Irish farmers. I have given the Deputy the facts and there is no come-back on them. What I have said about the limited trade from Uruguay, Spain and other countries——
Were there not 324,000 tons last year?
I told the Deputy that this was confined to calves and lightweights——
It is not.
Will Deputy Crinion please allow the debate to be concluded?

Again, Deputy Crinion is talking through his hat. Either he does not know or he does not want to know that the Commission do not issue licences. Any country prepared to carry the levy and the duty can import without a licence from the EEC. This is what we negotiated. These are the arrangements that we were prepared to accept and did accept. I did not accept them but the Government Party of which Deputy Crinion is a member accepted them. I am the first to say that I do not consider it was a bad bargain. Of course, we can get out of the EEC if we want to but that will certainly not do this country any good. The sooner Deputy Crinion grows up and ceases to wail about a good job being done, the better for Irish farmers.
